bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Surgeon General, May 13, 1919

div1.p: Carter suggests changes in the administrative policy of the US Public Health Service. He discusses regulations, examining boards, education of newly accepted candidates, examinations, specialization, rank, and compulsory waiting orders.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Surgeon General, May 13, 1919
div1.opener:
Suggestions in re changes
in the Regulations.
ASSISTANT SURGEON GENERAL H.R. CARTER
Regulations
May 13, 1919.
The Surgeon General,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I doubt if I should say anything in regard to the
changes in the Regulations to be shortly revised as requested
in Bureau letter of ______, because I have been ill and have
not been able to go over the present ones to give them de-
tailed consideration. I will however make one or two sugges-
tions.

(1) I think the Regulations should not go too much
in detail. In my judgement both of the last two revisions have
been opened to this objection. Let them be as clear as possi-
ble but Regulations that specify everything are not elastic
and are apt to hamper both the Bureau and officers who possess in-
itiative.

(2) Try to so arrange the Regulations so as to get
the best personnel and to get rid of the poor personnel. This
naturally is quite as much an affair of legislation in making
the Service attractive and of administration as of regulations.
For this:

(a) allow in the Regulations as much latitude as is
reasonably possible to the Examining Boards so that they will
2
have as free hand as possible, both in making the examination
and determining the values to be attached to the different
subjects. We, of course, should choose the best Boards pos-
sible and to change them as seldom as pozsible. I doubt how-
ever the wisdom of using the Bureau chiefs on such boards.
The choice of boards is, however, a matter of administration
not of regulations;

(b) If it be possible to arrange a school somewhat
on the Army plan for the newly accepted candidates, I think
it would be a very great advantage. They the accepted candidates would be appointed
Acting Assistant Surgeons until they had finished the course
and only those who proved satisfactory would be commissioned.
The Army is this able to require less of its candidates at
the first examination, thus saving some desirable men, because
it can judge of them again.in this school. Naturally the men
should also gain enormously from the school;

(c) The examination for P.A. should be used so
as to eliminate undesirable men more than it has been in the
past. Many a man has passed it who should not have done so
and whom it was not desirable to keep in the Service. In this
examination, I think the Board should be left free to allow
much weight to the officers record in the Service, so that if
it be good or very good it could make up for some professional
deficiency. This seems especially advisable if his service has
been in some non-professional branch, sanitary or otherwise.
If it be bad or very bad, it would require an extremely high
professional mark to pass. The present Regulations do not
3
allow as much latitude to the Boards in this as I would give
them and their past policy has been always to favor the offi-
cer at the expense of the Service, Although the “the ship is worth more
than the crew”, certainly than any member of it. The same policy
ishas obtained in the investigation and trial of officers.

(3) The present Regulations provides for certain
routine service of men on admission. It has not been carried
out but it is Regulations. The object, I was told, is to train
each man into every branch of the Service, to make him an “all
around man”. This to me is impossible and inadvisable. We
should rather specialize our men in the different lines of
work we do. They should be assigned to their special work
when it can be determined for what kind each one is most suit-
able and as soon as he has received the training needed and a-
vailable therefor. A Service school would help to determine
the first and provide the second. It would probably be ideal
for each man to spend- say- 2 or even 3 years in clinical work
which is good training for nearly everything. Is it possible? I doubt it.

All this, of course, is more administration than
Regulations, but I think the paragraph on assignment had best
be admitted. The Bureau can determine assignments better with-
out it. In any case I want to lay stress on my belief that
the specializing of officers in the different classes of Ser-
vice activities is essential for Service efficiency.

(4) I am inclined to think it advisable to make
the same difference between the Reserve Corps and Commissioned

Suggestions in re changes in
the Regulations.

H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General.

(4) I am inclined to think it advisable to made the same
difference between the Reserve Corps and Commissioned Officers that
exists between Staff and Line in the other Service, i. e. that the
C. O of the station be the Commissioned Officer. I am not certain
that this is always best, but generally I think it is. If the Re-
gulations be made unless “otherwise directed by the Bureau” it would
seem to meet this difficulty. Our men are usually more familiar
with administration than the Reserve Corps men, who are rather ex-
perts in their different lines--consultants whose advice in their
own lines, any reasonable man would ask and follow. Sometimes the
Reserve Corps men should be in charge, hence the proviso.

(5) If in accordance with the law--and I think it is--would
it not be well to give, in some cases, brevet rank, so to speak, by
the Reserve Corps Commission even to Commissioned Officers? I have
seen cases--Griffitts was, and Acker is, each a case in point.
Griffitts received sufficient salary, but a grade as Surgeon without
increase in salary had been an advantage to his work last year.
Acker if filling a Surgeon's place and his efficiency in dealing with
other men would be increased by another bar. I have seen a number of
similar cases. Here, it even makes a difference with the War Risk
Insurance patients. They have expressed themselves as lacking confi-
dence in “Lieutenant Doctors.” Of course, the importance of grade will
lessen, and I hope rapidly, with the end of the war. Still it is im-
portant now, decidedly so.

(6) If it be legal, I think waiting orders should be com-
pulsory at 64 years of age. The Bureau is the best judge of the
advisability of bringing this subject up.

H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General.
